Hire a tuk tuk: most journeys cost just 50 shillings.  Cheaper, greener and even more fun is a bicycle boda boda (ride pillion on the cushion over the back wheel): usually about 10 shillings.

value: content=After being turned away from Mombasa, it was here where the explorer Vasco de Gama landed. The pillar stands at the point where he came ashore.  Note that there is an entrance fee to see the pillar.
with its beautiful beaches and access to the marine park.

directions=From the Baobab bar/restaurant and walk towards the town. You will reach the House  of Columns jon your left after a about 5 minutes. From town it is just past the Beach Road Curio market, on your left.

content=Visit the museum which has very useful and interesting booklets for sale at low prices, and some exhibits. The museum is at present in the process of moving from its attractive and historic building 'The House of Columns' to a more historic building, recently renovated, 'The Old D.O's Office' near the easily noticed 'Sail Monument' (to Prince Henry the Navigator)where there are more exhibits. While you are in Malindi, why not join the Malindi Museum Society.You can do this at the House of Pillars (see above) as a visitor for Shs 600/- which gives free entry to all of the Museums of Kenya sites/buildings, not just in Malindi, but on the Coast.
content=There are plenty of places to hire kit, join a group or get instruction in the beach hotels
content=The huge, magnificent white beach north of the pier is just perfect.
content=Anywhere north of the Eden Roc from May to October.
content=There's a school north of the town.
content=Reasonable priced Pizzas, Seafood and Meat dishes. One of the longest running resturants in Malindi.
content=Restaurant open daily, as well as snack menu during the day. Popular curry lunch every Sunday overlooking the Indian Ocean.

, Lamu Road. Cheap and Cheerful. Rooms available on request.

Accommodation in Malindi is not expensive but its best recommended that you get a guest house.
